title: Border apprehensions drop for fourth straight month, acting CBP chief says
text:
September’s number of border arrests and people denied entry was the lowest monthly total for all of the 2019 fiscal year, which ran from Oct. 1, 2018, to Sept. 30. And the number of apprehensions and people found inadmissible last month was significantly lower than the peak in May of 144,000. In all, Morgan said, CBP's enforcement actions at the border totaled close to one million.

Those figures indicate that President Donald Trump's various attempts at curbing illegal immigration — a key promise of his presidency — may be having some effects, despite numerous legislative and legal setbacks.

Even without a breakdown of the number of border arrests for the year, Border Patrol has already apprehended the largest number of migrants crossing the southwest border since 2007, when they apprehended more than 858,000, according to CBP data.

And despite illegal immigration’s status as a pet issue for Trump, apprehensions in fiscal 2019 had already exploded relative to the year before, when Border Patrol reported nearly 400,000 for the entire year.

Morgan on Monday hailed September’s lower figures as “an unprecedented achievement,” noting that last month was the fourth month in a row that Border Patrol “averaged 25 percent lower than the last four months.”

He used the occasion to ding congressional Democrats for inaction on the surge of migrants coming to the border, proclaiming that "while Congress has failed to support a single piece of legislation, even introducing it to the floor, we have addressed the crisis."

Morgan also said that there was still work to be done, noting that though the number of daily border crossings had dropped from 5,000 four months ago to less than 1,700 presently, he aimed for a daily goal of 500.
